body:
Bumps [eslint-plugin-import](https://github.com/benmosher/eslint-plugin-import) from 2.20.0 to 2.20.1.
Changelog

Sourced from eslint-plugin-import's changelog.

[2.20.1] - 2020-02-01

Fixed

  • [export]: Handle function overloading in *.d.ts (#1619, thanks [@IvanGoncharov])
  • [no-absolute-path]: fix a crash with invalid import syntax (#1616, thanks [@ljharb])
  • [import/external-module-folders setting] now correctly works with directories containing modules symlinked from node_modules (#1605, thanks [@skozin])
  • [extensions]: for invalid code where name does not exist, do not crash (#1613, thanks [@ljharb])
  • [extentions]: Fix scope regex (#1611, thanks [@yordis])
  • [no-duplicates]: allow duplicate imports if one is a namespace and the other not (#1612, thanks [@sveyret])
  • Add some missing rule meta schemas and types (#1620, thanks [@bmish])
  • [named]: for importing from a module which re-exports named exports from a node_modules module (#1569, #1447, thanks [@redbugz], [@kentcdodds])
  • [order]: Fix alphabetize for mixed requires and imports (#5625, thanks [@wschurman])

Changed

  • [import/external-module-folders setting] behavior is more strict now: it will only match complete path segments (#1605, thanks [@skozin])
  • [meta] fix "files" field to include/exclude the proper files (#1635, thanks [@ljharb])
Commits
  • 45f0860 Bump to v2.20.1
  • 5d00854 [Fix] order: Fix alphabetize for mixed requires and imports
  • bbd166b [Fix] export: Handle function overloading in *.d.ts
  • 4665ec5 [Fix] no-absolute-path: fix a crash with invalid import syntax
  • 392c6b9 [Fix] named: for importing from a module which re-exports named exports fro...
  • cc5bde5 [Tests] named: add failing test for #1446
  • aff3a46 [meta] fix "files" field to include/exclude the proper files
  • 986ba74 docs: fix a few spelling mistakes
  • 6274d96 [Tests] set eslint-plugin/consistent-output lint rule to always require tes...
  • a4d301b [meta] add missing changelog links
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

body:
Bumps [@babel/preset-env](https://github.com/babel/babel) from 7.8.3 to 7.8.4.
Release notes

Sourced from @babel/preset-env's releases.

v7.8.4 (2020-01-30)

:warning: In Babel 7.8.0 we introduced the --copy-ignored option for @babel/cli, defaulting to false. However, previous versions behaved as if that option was present: for this reason, we changed its default value to true (when --copy-files is provided) and introduced a --no-copy-ignored option to disable it.

Thanks to @3cp, @BenoitZugmeyer, @pustovalov, @regiontog, and @vedantroy for their first PRs!

:eyeglasses: Spec Compliance

  • babel-parser
    • #11031 fix: properly parse member expression after property initializer (@vedantroy)
    • #11017 Update coalesce precedence (@JLHwung)
    • #11009 fix: triple __proto__ in object patterns should be allowed (@JLHwung)
    • #10987 Duplicate __proto__ key should be allowed in object patterns (@JLHwung)

:bug: Bug Fix

  • babel-cli
    • #11063 [@babel/cli] Copy ignored files by default (@nicolo-ribaudo)

Sourced from @babel/cli's changelog.

v7.8.4 (2020-01-30)

:warning: In Babel 7.8.0 we introduced the --copy-ignored option for @babel/cli, defaulting to false. However, previous versions behaved as if that option was present: for this reason, we changed its default value to true (when --copy-files is provided) and introduced a --no-copy-ignored option to disable it.

v2.18.0

2.18.0 (2020-01-27)

Bug Fixes

  • eslint-plugin: [explicit-module-boundary-types] false positive for returned fns (#1490) (5562ad5)

  • typescript-estree: error on unexpected jsdoc nodes (#1525) (c8dfac3)

body:
Bumps [rollup](https://github.com/rollup/rollup) from 1.29.1 to 1.30.1.
Release notes

Sourced from rollup's releases.

v1.30.1

2020-01-27

Bug Fixes

  • Do not mistreat static entgry points as dynamic ones when chunking (#3357)
  • Resolve a crash when chunking circular dynamic imports (#3357)

Pull Requests

  • #3357:Resolve issues with circular dynamic entries (@lukastaegert)

v1.30.0

2020-01-27

Features

  • Do not split chunks when dynamically imported modules import modules that are already loaded by all dynamic importers (#3354)
  • Add hoistTransitiveImports option to disable hoisting imports of static dependencies into entry chunks (#3353)

Bug Fixes

  • Make sure polyfills are always loaded first when each static entry point contains them as first import (#3354)

Pull Requests

  • #3353: Add option to avoid hoisting transitive imports (@lukastaegert)
  • #3354: Improve chunking algorithm for dynamic imports (@tjenkinson and @lukastaegert)
Changelog

Sourced from rollup's changelog.

1.30.1

2020-01-27

Bug Fixes

  • Do not mistreat static entgry points as dynamic ones when chunking (#3357)
  • Resolve a crash when chunking circular dynamic imports (#3357)

Pull Requests

  • #3357:Resolve issues with circular dynamic entries (@lukastaegert)

1.30.0

2020-01-27

Features

  • Do not split chunks when dynamically imported modules import modules that are already loaded by all dynamic importers (#3354)
  • Add hoistTransitiveImports option to disable hoisting imports of static dependencies into entry chunks (#3353)

Bug Fixes

  • Make sure polyfills are always loaded first when each static entry point contains them as first import (#3354)

Pull Requests

  • #3353: Add option to avoid hoisting transitive imports (@lukastaegert)
  • #3354: Improve chunking algorithm for dynamic imports (@tjenkinson and @lukastaegert)

  • 7fc24ab Improve chunking algorithm for dynamic imports (#3354)

body:
Bumps [husky](https://github.com/typicode/husky) from 3.1.0 to 4.2.0.
Release notes

Sourced from husky's releases.

v4.2.0

  • Check Git version during install and log an error if it's <2.13.0

v4.1.0

  • Improve speed and refactor hooks

v4.0.9

  • Fix: read stdin from hook script (#645)

v4.0.7

  • Fix: Yarn when running inside winpty (#634)

v4.0.6

  • Revert change in v4.0.5

v4.0.5

  • Fix: use process.exit if install fails #633

v4.0.4

  • Fix: npm ignore .eslintrc.js (#627)

v4.0.3

  • Fix: error message if trying to install in a non-git repo (#627)

v4.0.2

  • Fix: show error message when hook fails

v4.0.1

  • Fix: make Yarn silent. When Husky was installed with Yarn 1.21.1, hooks output was too verbose (#626).

v4.0.0

  • Support Yarn v2 new Plug'n'Play feature (thanks to @arcanis)
  • Improve path handling on Windows (in particular with Cygwin and Cmdr)
  • Remove dependencies and simplify code
  • Breaking requires Node 10+

Thanks to all contributors and everyone who is supporting Husky on Open Collective, GitHub sponsors and Patreon!

v4.0.0-beta.5

  • Fixes a bug in v4.0.0-beta.4

v4.0.0-beta.4

  • Rely on INIT_CWD env rather than node_modules path
  • Reduce dependencies: run-node, read-pkg
  • Target ES2017 environments
  • Support Cygwin and Cmdr on Windows

v4.0.0-beta.3

  • Reduce dependencies: remove execa typicode/husky#592 typicode/husky#590 typicode/husky#219
  • Merge changes from master since previous release
... (truncated)
Commits

Bumps [husky](https://github.com/typicode/husky) from 3.1.0 to 4.0.10.
Release notes

Sourced from husky's releases.

v4.0.9

  • Fix: read stdin from hook script (#645)

v4.0.7

  • Fix: Yarn when running inside winpty (#634)

v4.0.6

  • Revert change in v4.0.5

v4.0.5

  • Fix: use process.exit if install fails #633

v4.0.4

  • Fix: npm ignore .eslintrc.js (#627)

v4.0.3

  • Fix: error message if trying to install in a non-git repo (#627)

v4.0.2

  • Fix: show error message when hook fails

v4.0.1

  • Fix: make Yarn silent. When Husky was installed with Yarn 1.21.1, hooks output was too verbose (#626).

v4.0.0

  • Support Yarn v2 new Plug'n'Play feature (thanks to @arcanis)
  • Improve path handling on Windows (in particular with Cygwin and Cmdr)
  • Remove dependencies and simplify code
  • Breaking requires Node 10+

Thanks to all contributors and everyone who is supporting Husky on Open Collective, GitHub sponsors and Patreon!

v4.0.0-beta.5

  • Fixes a bug in v4.0.0-beta.4

v4.0.0-beta.4

  • Rely on INIT_CWD env rather than node_modules path
  • Reduce dependencies: run-node, read-pkg
  • Target ES2017 environments
  • Support Cygwin and Cmdr on Windows

v4.0.0-beta.3

  • Merge changes from master since previous release

body: This is the API we have in v3, so some people might rely on this? It also makes sense to me to access it before instantiation. If you disagree, no hard feelings :)
comments: I think we should avoid mutating our exports like this. I believe bundlers consider this as a side effect. Why not export `version` the normal way?

Context, with this pull request we allow to get the version in 3 different ways:
- 1 - module `import { version } from '@algolia/common'.
- 2 - instance `client.version`
- 3 - constructor: `algoliasearch.version`.

>  I believe bundlers consider this as a side effect

I didn't think of that, do you have a link for that?

@francoischalifour @Haroenv Feedback: when you put `sideEffects: false` bundlers will assume that there is no side effects at all - He will not even search for side effects. 

Second, adding a property to an object (`algoliasearch`) exported by our module could never be a side effect.

@Haroenv I agree with @francoischalifour that we should just provide two ways of getting the version.

1. on the modular way `import { version } from '@algolia/common'.`.
2. on the preset way `import { version } from 'PRESET';`

If you agree, I can clean up this pull request, and adapt it.

@Haroenv I think it came up when talking with @samouss. I can't find many resources on this topic. Webpack's guide on [Tree Shaking](https://webpack.js.org/guides/tree-shaking/) is interesting but doesn't talk about what is considered as a side effect.
commit_messages: feat(version): expose version on presets (#951)

Release notes

Fixed

  • Downgrade yn due to node engine (#942)

Fix compiler options from environment

Fixed

  • Fix the resolution order of TS_NODE_COMPILER_OPTIONS - closes TypeStrong/ts-node#938

Compiler Host API

Fixed

  • Remove normalize slashes from config file loading for Windows

Added

  • Configure using tsconfig.json (#921) @cspotcode üéâ
  • Allow dir to be configurable
  • Add --build flag for emitting compiled TypeScript (under --compiler-host mode)
  • Incremental compiler support (#895)

body:
Bumps [husky](https://github.com/typicode/husky) from 3.1.0 to 4.0.7.
Release notes

Sourced from husky's releases.

v4.0.7

  • Fix Yarn when running inside winpty (#634)

v4.0.6

  • Revert change in v4.0.5

v4.0.5

  • Fix: use process.exit if install fails #633

v4.0.4

  • Fix: npm ignore .eslintrc.js (#627)

v4.0.3

  • Fix: error message if trying to install in a non-git repo (#627)

v4.0.2

  • Fix: show error message when hook fails

v4.0.1

  • Fix: make Yarn silent. When Husky was installed with Yarn 1.21.1, hooks output was too verbose (#626).

v4.0.0

  • Support Yarn v2 new Plug'n'Play feature (thanks to @arcanis)
  • Improve path handling on Windows (in particular with Cygwin and Cmdr)
  • Remove dependencies and simplify code
  • Breaking requires Node 10+

Thanks to all contributors and everyone who is supporting Husky on Open Collective, GitHub sponsors and Patreon!

v4.0.0-beta.5

  • Fixes a bug in v4.0.0-beta.4

v4.0.0-beta.4

  • Rely on INIT_CWD env rather than node_modules path
  • Reduce dependencies: run-node, read-pkg
  • Target ES2017 environments
  • Support Cygwin and Cmdr on Windows

v4.0.0-beta.3

  • Reduce dependencies: remove execa typicode/husky#592 typicode/husky#590 typicode/husky#219
  • Merge changes from master since previous release

v4.0.0-beta.2

Merge bug fixes from v3 since v4.0.0-beta.1 was released.

v4.0.0-beta.1

Fix: yarn run error (typicode/husky#562)

v4.0.0-beta.0

This is an experimental release with Yarn PnP support.

body: This method returns a promise, but in the default implementation, clearing the cache is actually instant, so the promises don't _need_ to be awaited.
commit_messages:
feat(searchClient): add clearCache method, which clears request & response caches (#937)

* feat(searchClient): add clearCache method, which clears request & response caches

This method returns a promise, but in the default implementation, clearing the cache is actually instant, so the promises don't _need_ to be awaited.

* chore: update bundle size

body:
Bumps [husky](https://github.com/typicode/husky) from 3.1.0 to 4.0.5.
Release notes

Sourced from husky's releases.

v4.0.5

  • Fix: use process.exit if install fails #633

v4.0.4

  • Fix: npm ignore .eslintrc.js (#627)

v4.0.3

  • Fix: error message if trying to install in a non-git repo (#627)

v4.0.2

  • Fix: show error message when hook fails

v4.0.1

  • Fix: make Yarn silent. When Husky was installed with Yarn 1.21.1, hooks output was too verbose (#626).

v4.0.0

  • Support Yarn v2 new Plug'n'Play feature (thanks to @arcanis)
  • Improve path handling on Windows (in particular with Cygwin and Cmdr)
  • Remove dependencies and simplify code
  • Breaking requires Node 10+

Thanks to all contributors and everyone who is supporting Husky on Open Collective, GitHub sponsors and Patreon!

v4.0.0-beta.5

  • Fixes a bug in v4.0.0-beta.4

v4.0.0-beta.4

  • Rely on INIT_CWD env rather than node_modules path
  • Reduce dependencies: run-node, read-pkg
  • Target ES2017 environments
  • Support Cygwin and Cmdr on Windows

v4.0.0-beta.3

  • Reduce dependencies: remove execa typicode/husky#592 typicode/husky#590 typicode/husky#219
  • Merge changes from master since previous release

v4.0.0-beta.2

Merge bug fixes from v3 since v4.0.0-beta.1 was released.

v4.0.0-beta.1

Fix: yarn run error (typicode/husky#562)

v4.0.0-beta.0

This is an experimental release with Yarn PnP support. Huge thanks to @arcanis for the help.

Commits
  • 3157ff4 4.0.5
  • b661673 fix: use process.exit if install fails (#633)
  • 8006363 4.0.4

  • 03b72bf 4.0.3
  • 63d6776 fix error message if trying to install in a non-git repo
  • e3f7fc8 4.0.2
  • d6ecc9d fix show error message if hook fails
  • 3ca7ff4 4.0.1
  • af80769 Update README.md
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

body:
Bumps [rollup](https://github.com/rollup/rollup) from 1.27.14 to 1.28.0.
Release notes

Sourced from rollup's releases.

v1.28.0

2020-01-04

Features

  • Allow piping in stdin via the command line interface (#3312, #3290)
  • Allow plugins to mark modules as having syntheticNamedExports for e.g. better CJS interoperability (#3295)
  • Ignore variable reassignments in dead code when tree-shaking to remove more unneeded code (#3212)

Bug Fixes

  • Properly respect tree-shaken code when generating sourcemaps (#3318)

Pull Requests

  • #3212: Handle assignments in dead code (@tjenkinson)
  • #3290: Implement stdin input with optional "-" as the file name (@kzc)
  • #3295: Add syntheticNamedExports (@manucorporat)
  • #3300: Add note about setting types in tsconfig file (@tjenkinson)
  • #3303: Use ! to assert not-null in TypeScript (@NotWoods)
  • #3312: Implement stdin input (@lukastaegert)
  • #3318: Update magic-string and other dependencies (@lukastaegert)
Changelog

Sourced from rollup's changelog.

1.28.0

2020-01-04

Features

  • Allow piping in stdin via the command line interface (#3312, #3290)
  • Allow plugins to mark modules as having syntheticNamedExports for e.g. better CJS interoperability (#3295)
  • Ignore variable reassignments in dead code when tree-shaking to remove more unneeded code (#3212)

Bug Fixes

  • Properly respect tree-shaken code when generating sourcemaps (#3318)

body:
Bumps [eslint-plugin-functional](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional) from 1.0.3 to 2.0.0.
Release notes

Sourced from eslint-plugin-functional's releases.

2.0.0

Changes of note

  • External recommended eslint rules are no longer included in rulesets by default; they now live in their own ruleset call external-recommended.

Example of how to use:

{
  "parser": "@typescript-eslint/parser",
  "plugins": ["@typescript-eslint", "functional"],
  "extends": [
    "eslint:recommended",
    "plugin:@typescript-eslint/eslint-recommended",
    "plugin:@typescript-eslint/recommended",
    "plugin:functional/external-recommended", // loaded here.
    "plugin:functional/recommended"
  ],
  "parserOptions": {
    "project": "tsconfig.json",
    "sourceType": "module"
  }
}
  • The lite ruleset will no longer enforce a minimal parameter count (with regard to rule functional-parameters). See #79 for details.
Changelog

Sourced from eslint-plugin-functional's changelog.

v2.0.0 - 2019-12-29

Merged

  • build(deps): bump handlebars from 4.1.2 to 4.5.3 [#84](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional/issues/84)
  • Do not enforce a parameter count by default in the lite ruleset [#83](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional/issues/83)
  • Add a section to explicitly list all the rulesets [#77](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional/issues/77)
  • no longer include external recommended rules in the rulesets; put them in their own ruleset [#80](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional/issues/80)

Fixed

  • feat(functional-parameters): do not enforce a parameter count by default in the lite ruleset [#79](https://github.com/jonaskello/eslint-plugin-functional/issues/79)

Release notes

Sourced from @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin's releases.

v2.14.0

2.14.0 (2019-12-30)

Bug Fixes

  • eslint-plugin: type assertion in rule no-extra-parens (#1376) (f40639e)
  • typescript-estree: visit typeParameters in OptionalCallExpr (#1377) (cba6a2a)

Features

  • add internal eslint plugin for repo-specific lint rules (#1373) (3a15413)

v2.13.0

2.13.0 (2019-12-23)

Bug Fixes

  • eslint-plugin: [quotes] ignore backticks for Enum members (#1355) (e51048c)
  • eslint-plugin: [type-annotation-spacing] typo in messages (#1354) (82e0dbc)
  • eslint-plugin: add isTypeAssertion utility function (#1369) (bb1671e)
  • eslint-plugin: use AST_NODE_TYPES enum instead of strings (#1366) (bd0276b)
  • typescript-estree: correct type of key for base nodes (#1367) (099225a)

Features

  • eslint-plugin: [ban-types] handle empty type literal {} (#1348) (1c0ce9b)

  • eslint-plugin: more optional chain support in rules (#1363) (3dd1b02)

  • typescript-estree: computed members discriminated unions (#1349) (013df9a)
  • typescript-estree: tighten prop name and destructure types (#1346) (f335c50)

Bumps [eslint](https://github.com/eslint/eslint) from 6.7.2 to 6.8.0.
Release notes

Sourced from eslint's releases.

v6.8.0

  • c5c7086 Fix: ignore aligning single line in key-spacing (fixes #11414) (#12652) (YeonJuan)
  • 9986d9e Chore: add object option test cases in yield-star-spacing (#12679) (YeonJuan)
  • 1713d07 New: Add no-error-on-unmatched-pattern flag (fixes #10587) (#12377) (ncraley)
  • 5c25a26 Update: autofix bug in lines-between-class-members (fixes #12391) (#12632) (YeonJuan)
  • 4b3cc5c Chore: enable prefer-regex-literals in eslint codebase (#12268) (ËñõÂÆöË∞îÁöÑÁå´)
  • 05faebb Update: improve suggestion testing experience (#12602) (Brad Zacher)
  • 05f7dd5 Update: Add suggestions for no-unsafe-negation (fixes #12591) (#12609) (Milos Djermanovic)
  • d3e43f1 Docs: Update no-multi-assign explanation (#12615) (Yuping Zuo)
  • 272e4db Fix: no-multiple-empty-lines: Adjust reported loc (#12594) (Tobias Bieniek)
  • a258039 Fix: no-restricted-imports schema allows multiple paths/patterns objects (#12639) (Milos Djermanovic)
  • 51f9620 Fix: improve report location for array-bracket-spacing (#12653) (Milos Djermanovic)
  • 45364af Fix: prefer-numeric-literals doesn't check types of literal arguments (#12655) (Milos Djermanovic)
  • e3c570e Docs: Add example for expression option (#12694) (Arnaud Barr√©)
  • 6b774ef Docs: Add spacing in comments for no-console rule (#12696) (Nikki Nikkhoui)
  • 7171fca Chore: refactor regex in config comment parser (#12662) (Milos Djermanovic)

  • 49c1658 Chore: remove bundling of ESLint during release (#12676) (Kai Cataldo)
  • 257f3d6 Chore: complete to move to GitHub Actions (#12625) (Toru Nagashima)
  • ab912f0 Docs: 1tbs with allowSingleLine edge cases (refs #12284) (#12314) (Ari Kardasis)
  • dd1c30e Sponsors: Sync README with website (ESLint Jenkins)

  • 8b65f17 Chore: remove references to parser demo (#12644) (Kai Cataldo)

Bumps [replace-in-file](https://github.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file) from 4.2.0 to 5.0.2.
Changelog *Sourced from [replace-in-file's changelog](https://github.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).* > ## 5.0.0 > From version 5.0.0 onwards, replace in file requires Node 8 or higher. If you need support for Node 6, please use version 4.x.x. > > ## 4.0.0 > > ### Breaking changes > The return value is now a results array instead of an array with changed files. The new results array includes each file that was processed, with a flag to indicate whether or not the file was changed, and optionally information about the number of matches and replacements that were made. See the readme for more details. > > To update existing code and obtain an array of changed files again, simply convert the results array as follows: > > ```js > const results = await replace(options); > const changedFiles = results > .filter(result => result.hasChanged) > .map(result => result.file); > ``` > > ### New features > - Added `countMatches` flag to count the number of matches and replacements per file [#38](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/issues/38), [#42](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/issues/42), [#61](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/issues/61) > - Added `--quiet` flag for CLI to suppress success output [#63](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/issues/63) > - Added `cwd` configuration parameter for network drive replacements [#56](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/adamreisnz/replace-in-file/issues/56) > > ## 3.0.0 > > ### Breaking changes > From version 3.0.0 onwards, replace in file requires Node 6 or higher. If you need support for Node 4 or 5, please use version 2.x.x.

Bumps [rollup](https://github.com/rollup/rollup) from 1.27.4 to 1.27.7.
Release notes *Sourced from [rollup's releases](https://github.com/rollup/rollup/releases).* > ## v1.27.7 > *2019-12-01* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Fix a scenario where a reassignments to computed properties were not tracked ([#3267](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3267)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3267](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3267): Fix incomplete computed property deoptimization ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > > ## v1.27.6 > *2019-11-30* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Use "auto" export mode by default for all modules when preserving modules ([#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3265)) > * Observe "output.exports" when preserving modules and warn for mixed exports if necessary ([#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3265)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3265): Use export mode "auto" by default when preserving modules ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > > ## v1.27.5 > *2019-11-25* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Make sure namespaces for inlined dynamic imports are treated as variable accesses when deconflicting ([#3256](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3256)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3256](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3256): Avoid name conflicts when inlining dynamic imports nested in functions ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > * [#3257](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3257): Update dependencies ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) >
Changelog *Sourced from [rollup's changelog](https://github.com/rollup/rollup/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).* > ## 1.27.7 > *2019-12-01* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Fix a scenario where a reassignments to computed properties were not tracked ([#3267](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3267)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3267](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3267): Fix incomplete computed property deoptimization ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > > ## 1.27.6 > *2019-11-30* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Use "auto" export mode by default for all modules when preserving modules ([#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3265)) > * Observe "output.exports" when preserving modules and warn for mixed exports if necessary ([#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3265)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3265](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3265): Use export mode "auto" by default when preserving modules ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > > ## 1.27.5 > *2019-11-25* > > ### Bug Fixes > * Make sure namespaces for inlined dynamic imports are treated as variable accesses when deconflicting ([#3256](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/issues/3256)) > > ### Pull Requests > * [#3256](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3256): Avoid name conflicts when inlining dynamic imports nested in functions ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert)) > * [#3257](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/rollup/rollup/pull/3257): Update dependencies ([@​lukastaegert](https://github.com/lukastaegert))

([@​nicolo-ribaudo](https://github.com/nicolo-ribaudo)) > * `babel-preset-env` > * [#10742](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/babel/babel/pull/10742) Update preset-env mappings. ([@​existentialism](https://github.com/existentialism)) > * `babel-parser` > * [#10737](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/babel/babel/pull/10737) Flow enums: fix enum body location. body:
Bumps [fstream](https://github.com/npm/fstream) from 1.0.11 to 1.0.12. **This update includes a security fix.**
Vulnerabilities fixed *Sourced from The GitHub Security Advisory Database.* > **Moderate severity vulnerability that affects fstream** > Versions of fstream prior to 1.0.12 are vulnerable to Arbitrary File Overwrite. > > Affected versions: < 1.0.12
Commits - [`4235459`](https://github.com/npm/fstream/commit/42354590e23bb514eb5c869eea64406be2947c6c) 1.0.12 - [`6a77d2f`](https://github.com/npm/fstream/commit/6a77d2fa6e1462693cf8e46f930da96ec1b0bb22) Clobber a Link if it's in the way of a File - See full diff in [compare view](https://github.com/npm/fstream/compare/v1.0.11...v1.0.12)

OK, I won't notify you again about this release, but will get in touch when a new version is available. If you'd rather skip all updates until the next major or minor version, let me know by commenting `@dependabot ignore this major version` or `@dependabot ignore this minor version`.

If you change your mind, just re-open this PR and I'll resolve any conflicts on it.

body:
Bumps [eslint-plugin-react](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react) from 3.16.1 to 5.2.2.
Release notes *Sourced from [eslint-plugin-react's releases](https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/releases).* > ## v5.2.2 > ### Fixed > - Fix `jsx-no-bind` crash ([#641](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/641)) > > ## v5.2.1 > ### Fixed > - Fix `jsx-pascal-case` for namespaced components ([#637](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/637) [@​evcohen](https://github.com/evcohen)) > > ## v5.2.0 > ### Added > - Add `require-optimization` rule ([#240](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/240) [@​EvNaverniouk](https://github.com/EvNaverniouk)) > - Add `jsx-filename-extension` rule ([#495](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/495) [@​lencioni](https://github.com/lencioni)) > - Add `no-render-return-value` rule ([#531](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/531) [@​iamdustan](https://github.com/iamdustan)) > - Add `no-comment-textnodes` rule ([#616](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/pull/616) [@​benvinegar](https://github.com/benvinegar)) > - Add `objectLiterals` option to `jsx-curly-spacing` ([#388](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/388), [#211](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/211) [@​casesandberg](https://github.com/casesandberg) [@​ljharb](https://github.com/ljharb)) > - Add option to `self-closing-comp` to check html tags ([#572](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/572) [@​gitim](https://github.com/gitim)) > - Add `ignore` option to `no-unknown-property` rule ([#631](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/pull/631) [@​insin](https://github.com/insin)) > - Add support for ES7 bind operator to `jsx-handler-names` ([#630](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/630)) > - Add support for explicit declaration that class extends React.Component ([#68](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/68) [@​gausie](https://github.com/gausie)) > > ### Fixed > - body:
Bumps [extend](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend) from 3.0.1 to 3.0.2. **This update includes a security fix.**
Vulnerabilities fixed *Sourced from The GitHub Security Advisory Database.* > **Low severity vulnerability that affects extend** > A prototype pollution vulnerability was found in module extend <2.0.2, ~<3.0.2 that allows an attacker to inject arbitrary properties onto Object.prototype. > > Affected versions: >= 3.0.0 < 3.0.2
Changelog *Sourced from [extend's changelog](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).* > 3.0.2 / 2018-07-19 > ================== > * [Fix] Prevent merging `__proto__` property ([#48](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/justmoon/node-extend/issues/48)) > * [Dev Deps] update `eslint`, `@ljharb/eslint-config`, `tape` > * [Tests] up to `node` `v10.7`, `v9.11`, `v8.11`, `v7.10`, `v6.14`, `v4.9`; use `nvm install-latest-npm`
Commits - [`8d106d2`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/8d106d23931c0802e8b88188b0aac433e13358d9) v3.0.2 - [`e97091f`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/e97091fa7557e106042e475ef59e654fa9d2c7ab) [Dev Deps] update `tape` - [`e841aac`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/e841aac7ce7119606345b440b0a9e7668e848985) [Tests] up to `node` `v10.7` - [`0e68e71`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/0e68e71d93507fcc391e398bc84abd0666b28190) [Fix] Prevent merging __proto__ property - [`a689700`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/a689700740b44846e76f8f1dc4bdf230a2cb5c0d) Only apps should have lockfiles - [`f13c1c4`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/f13c1c4e51c47b90604eb2dc56cc60561e497d36) [Dev Deps] update `eslint`, `@ljharb/eslint-config`, `tape` - [`f3570fe`](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/commit/f3570fe5582dbfba47e60c0cd75b4fb6f01cd3fe) [Tests] up to `node` `v10.0`, `v9.11`, `v8.11`, `v7.10`, `v6.14`, `v4.9`; use... - See full diff in [compare view](https://github.com/justmoon/node-extend/compare/v3.0.1...v3.0.2)

Bumps [concat-stream](https://github.com/maxogden/concat-stream) from 1.4.10 to 1.4.11. **This update includes security fixes.**
Vulnerabilities fixed *Sourced from [The Node Security Working Group](https://github.com/nodejs/security-wg/blob/master/vuln/npm/392.json).* > **Memory Exposure** > .write(number) in the affected `concat-stream` versions passes a number to Buffer constructor, appending a chunk of uninitialized memory. Versions <1.3.0 are not affected due to not using unguarded Buffer constructor. > > Affected versions: >=1.3.0 <1.3.2 || >=1.4.0 <1.4.11 || >=1.5.0 <1.5.2 *Sourced from [The Node Security Working Group](https://github.com/nodejs/security-wg/blob/master/vuln/npm/392.json).* > **Memory Exposure** > .write(number) in the affected `concat-stream` versions passes a number to Buffer constructor, appeding a chunk of unitialized memory. Versions <1.3.0 are not affected due to not using unguarded Buffer constructor. > > Affected versions: >=1.3.0 <1.3.2 || >=1.4.0 <1.4.11 || >=1.5.0 <1.5.2

body:
Bumps [async](https://github.com/caolan/async) from 1.5.2 to 3.1.0.
Release notes *Sourced from [async's releases](https://github.com/caolan/async/releases).* > ## v2.3.0 > - Added support for ES2017 `async` functions. Wherever you can pass a Node-style/CPS function that uses a callback, you can also pass an `async` function. Previously, you had to wrap `async` functions with `asyncify`. The caveat is that it will only work if `async` functions are supported natively in your environment, transpiled implementations can't be detected. ([#1386](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1386), [#1390](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1390)) > > ## v2.2.0 > - Added `groupBy`, and the `Series`/`Limit` equivalents, analogous to [`_.groupBy`](http://lodash.com/docs#groupBy) ([#1364](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1364)) > - Fixed `transform` bug when `callback` was not passed ([#1381](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1381)) > > ## v2.1.5 > - Fix `auto` bug when function names collided with Array.prototype ([#1358](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1358)) > - Improve some error messages ([#1349](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1349)) > - Avoid stack overflow case in queue > - Fixed an issue in `some`, `every` and `find` where processing would continue after the result was determined. > - Cleanup implementations of `some`, `every` and `find` > > ## v2.1.3 > - Make bundle size smaller > - Create optimized hotpath for `filter` in array case. > > ## v2.1.2 > - Fixed a stackoverflow bug with `detect`, `some`, `every` on large inputs ([#1293](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1293)). > > ## v2.1.0 > - `retry` and `retryable` now support an optional `errorFilter` function that determines if the `task` should retry on the error ([#1256](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1256), [#1261](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1261)) > - Optimized array iteration in `race`, `cargo`, `queue`, and `priorityQueue` ([#1253](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1253)) > > ## v2.0.0 > Lots of changes here! > > First and foremost, we have a slick new [site for docs](https://caolan.github.io/async/). Special thanks to [**[@​hargasinski](https://github.com/hargasinski)**](https://github.com/hargasinski) for his work converting our old docs to `jsdoc` format and implementing the new website. Also huge ups to [**[@​ivanseidel](https://github.com/ivanseidel)**](https://github.com/ivanseidel) for designing our new logo. It was a long process for both of these tasks, but I think these changes turned out extraordinary well. > > The biggest feature is modularization. You can now `require("async/series")` to only require the `series` function. Every Async library function is available this way. You still can `require("async")` to require the entire library, like you could do before. > > We also provide Async as a collection of ES2015 modules. You can now `import {each} from 'async-es'` or `import waterfall from 'async-es/waterfall'`. If you are using only a few Async functions, and are using a ES bundler such as Rollup, this can significantly lower your build size. > > Major thanks to [**[@​Kikobeats](https://github.com/Kikobeats)**](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/HEAD/github.com/Kikobeats), [**[@​aearly](https://github.com/aearly)**](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/HEAD/github.com/aearly) and [**[@​megawac](https://github.com/megawac)**](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/HEAD/github.com/megawac) for doing the majority of the modularization work, as well as [**[@​jdalton](https://github.com/jdalton)**](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/HEAD/github.com/jdalton) and [**[@​Rich-Harris](https://github.com/Rich-Harris)**](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/HEAD/github.com/Rich-Harris) for advisory work on the general modularization strategy. > > Another one of the general themes of the 2.0 release is standardization of what an "async" function is. We are now more strictly following the node-style continuation passing style. That is, an async function is a function that: > > 1. Takes a variable number of arguments > 2. The last argument is always a callback > 3. The callback can accept any number of arguments > 4. The first argument passed to the callback will be treated as an error result, if the argument is truthy > 5. Any number of result arguments can be passed after the "error" argument > 6. The callback is called once and exactly once, either on the same tick or later tick of the JavaScript event loop. > > There were several cases where Async accepted some functions that did not strictly have these properties, most notably `auto`, `every`, `some`, and `filter`. > > Another theme is performance. We have eliminated internal deferrals in all cases where they make sense. For example, in `waterfall` and `auto`, there was a `setImmediate` between each task -- these deferrals have been removed. A `setImmediate` call can add up to 1ms of delay. This might not seem like a lot, but it can add up if you are using many Async functions in the course of processing a HTTP request, for example. Nearly all asynchronous functions that do I/O already have some sort of deferral built in, so the extra deferral is unnecessary. The trade-off of this change is removing our built-in stack-overflow defense. Many synchronous callback calls in series can quickly overflow the JS call stack. If you do have a function that is sometimes synchronous (calling its callback on the same tick), and are running into stack overflows, wrap it with `async.ensureAsync()`. > > Another big performance win has been re-implementing `queue`, `cargo`, and `priorityQueue` with [doubly linked lists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doubly_linked_list) instead of arrays. This has lead to queues being an order of [magnitude faster on large sets of tasks](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/pull/1205). > ... (truncated)
Changelog *Sourced from [async's changelog](https://github.com/caolan/async/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).* > # v3.1.0 > > - Added `q.pushAsync` and `q.unshiftAsync`, analagous to `q.push` and `q.unshift`, except they always do not accept a callback, and reject if processing the task errors. ([#1659](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1659)) > - Promises returned from `q.push` and `q.unshift` when a callback is not passed now resolve even if an error ocurred. ([#1659](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1659)) > - Fixed a parsing bug in `autoInject` with complicated function bodies ([#1663](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1663)) > - Added ES6+ configuration for Browserify bundlers ([#1653](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1653)) > - Various doc fixes ([#1664](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1664), [#1658](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1658), [#1665](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1665), [#1652](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1652)) > > # v3.0.1 > > ## Bug fixes > - Fixed a regression where arrays passed to `queue` and `cargo` would be completely flattened. ([#1645](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1645)) > - Clarified Async's browser support ([#1643](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1643)) > > > # v3.0.0 > > The `async`/`await` release! > > There are a lot of new features and subtle breaking changes in this major version, but the biggest feature is that most Async methods return a Promise if you omit the callback, meaning you can `await` them from within an `async` function. > > ```js > const results = await async.mapLimit(urls, 5, async url => { > const resp = await fetch(url) > return resp.body > }) > ``` > > ## Breaking Changes > - Most Async methods return a Promise when the final callback is omitted, making them `await`-able! ([#1572](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1572)) > - We are now making heavy use of ES2015 features, this means we have dropped out-of-the-box support for Node 4 and earlier, and many old versions of browsers. ([#1541](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1541), [#1553](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1553)) > - In `queue`, `priorityQueue`, `cargo` and `cargoQueue`, the "event"-style methods, like `q.drain` and `q.saturated` are now methods that register a callback, rather than properties you assign a callback to. They are now of the form `q.drain(callback)`. If you do not pass a callback a Promise will be returned for the next occurrence of the event, making them `await`-able, e.g. `await q.drain()`. ([#1586](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1586), [#1641](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1641)) > - Calling `callback(false)` will cancel an async method, preventing further iteration and callback calls. This is useful for preventing memory leaks when you break out of an async flow by calling an outer callback. ([#1064](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1064), [#1542](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1542)) > - `during` and `doDuring` have been removed, and instead `whilst`, `doWhilst`, `until` and `doUntil` now have asynchronous `test` functions. ([#850](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/850), [#1557](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1557)) > - `limits` of less than 1 now cause an error to be thrown in queues and collection methods. ([#1249](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1249), [#1552](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1552)) > - `memoize` no longer memoizes errors ([#1465](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1465), [#1466](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1466)) > - `applyEach`/`applyEachSeries` have a simpler interface, to make them more easily type-able. It always returns a function that takes in a single callback argument. If that callback is omitted, a promise is returned, making it awaitable. ([#1228](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1228), [#1640](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1640)) > > ## New Features > - Async generators are now supported in all the Collection methods. ([#1560](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1560)) > - Added `cargoQueue`, a queue with both `concurrency` and `payload` size parameters. ([#1567](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1567)) > - Queue objects returned from `queue` now have a `Symbol.iterator` method, meaning they can be iterated over to inspect the current list of items in the queue. ([#1459](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1459), [#1556](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1556)) > - A ESM-flavored `async.mjs` is included in the `async` package. This is described in the `package.json` `"module"` field, meaning it should be automatically used by Webpack and other compatible bundlers. > > ## Bug fixes > - Better handle arbitrary error objects in `asyncify` ([#1568](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1568), [#1569](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1569)) > > ## Other > - Removed Lodash as a dependency ([#1283](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1283), [#1528](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1528)) > - Miscellaneous docs fixes ([#1393](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1393), [#1501](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1501), [#1540](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1540), [#1543](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1543), [#1558](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1558), [#1563](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1563), [#1564](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1564), [#1579](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1579), [#1581](https://github-redirect.dependabot.com/caolan/async/issues/1581)) > ... (truncated)

body:
**Summary**

This pull request fixes an issue when people try to find and object without pagination, setting `paginate` to false,  using the `findObject` method. Without the `delete` code introduced in this pull request, the engine returns: `Unknown parameter: paginate`.
comments: Thanks for forcing test quality. Just added tests.
commit_messages: fix: unknown parameter `paginate` within findObjects method (#796)

body:
**Summary**
Reopened PR that prevents empty strings to be passed as an `objectId` when using `index.deleteObject`. The last PR was introducing a breaking change throwing an error when someone gaves a `0` as an objectId (and this was not valid). As explained in this comment: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/pull/789#issuecomment-542104709

Related issue: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/issues/755

**Result**
* Breaking change fixed. Now `0` is a valid object id.
* Also I've took the opportunity to test some uncovered cases: (https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/commit/c740877137240cc688b6fec36db557b338c0fd2d#diff-7f406cf06aa9340c5d564bde813b50f2)
  * When `deleteObject('id')` with a valid object id
  * When `deleteObject('id', cb)` with a valid object id and a callback
comments: Updated the base of this pull request.
@Haroenv Now that we have the v4 out, I would prefer to freeze the v3 completely. I was thinking about not merging this pull request as there is no actually bug on the method.
I'm not sure if this isn't a bug, since v3 _does_ have safe programming. I'm ok with closing it though (definitely thank @alexhoma for your time making this PR), since it's fixed in v4
Yes - thanks @alexhoma !
Thanks @aseure !

body:
**Summary**
Using `index.deleteObject` passing an empty string on the `objectID` deletes the index. And should throw an `AlgoliaSearchError`. Here's the linked issue: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/issues/755

**Result**
Once repository was cloned, I've executed `yarn` to install dependencies and `yarn test`.

I've added a test to cover the "empty string" case and then I've added the guard clause on the production code. (https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/pull/789/commits/eadd2e35b74f3b6f1f593862317b0129c6387e8e)
Then, I've tried to refactor the checks of the `objectID`. I think I've improved legibility, but if not, we can avoid the last commit :) (https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/pull/789/commits/fb91860febba366f8d142a288a3cb58d1d5903ee)

**Notes**
- I'd like to discuss if we can add a test case when someone passes an empty string but its length is not 0, like: `"     "`. With the current code, this could not happen, but there is no test that prevents someone to break this.
- And another test to check if someone passes a number. Now I've seen that there is a guard that covers if `objectID` is not a number, but when I remove this condition, tests are green anyway.

body:
Added a method to check if the index exists

**Summary**

This is self-explanatory. It adds a method on the index to check if it exists or not. You can check the specification here https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/issues/768

**Results**

You can either call `index.exists.then( ... )` or `index.exists(function(err, content) { ... });`. It will return `true` if the index exists and `false` if we get a 404 AlgoliaSearchError. Any other errors is thrown.

body:
**Summary**

This PR adds formatting and linting to the project:

- Prettier and ESLint (with the [Algolia configuration](https://github.com/algolia/eslint-config-algolia))
- EditorConfig

Linting can be performed manually. Additionally, every attempt to commit triggers linting (with Husky and lint-staged).

The idea is to ensure we don't commit anything "dirty" and avoid breaking a build because of linting errors. This reduces (if not completely removes) the need for "style" commits.

**Result**

To test this, try to:

- Add a JavaScript or TypeScript file with incorrect formatting or rule violations.
- Run `yarn lint`, this should raise errors.
- Stage the faulty file and try to commit it, this should raise errors as well.
- Run `yarn lint:fix`, this should take care of fixable issues.

![lint](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5370675/60455176-10785780-9c36-11e9-89fa-bc4e10e28db8.gif)

body:
**Summary**

This PR exposes the reverse geocoding endpoint of Places in the JS client through a `.reverse(options, callback)` method. This would allow the places.js library to leverage the power of js client wrt to retry strategy and caching.

**Result**

Usage
```js
const places = algoliasearch.initPlaces(appId, apiKey);

places.reverse({
  aroundLatLng: '48.880397,2.32699',
  language: 'en',
  getRankingInfo: true,
  hitsPerPage: 20
});
```

Response

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5136989/49367852-82fb7600-f6ed-11e8-9de0-6ba7481d5023.png)

**Notes:**
- the way the reverse API accepts arguments is slightly different from a standard endpoint and will fail if passed a body with params. The parameters have to be passed as search parameters in the url. Which is unfortunate because I could have used `buildSearchMethod('reverse', '/1/places/reverse')` if it was standard.
- I wasn't sure how recent the syntax could be so I went for ES3 (use of `concat`). If you have a more recent syntax that would improve readability, or if I should update my code for an older target, please let me know.

body:
**Summary**

This PR update the strategy for caching the requests. With the current implementation we cache the results when we receive the response. It means that when we perform multiple exact same requests in parallel the client will trigger multiple network requests. 

This PR introduce a different approach, we cache the promise of the requests. Now when multiple exact same requests are triggered in parallel the same promise is reused for all the requests. Only one network call can be trigger for a request.

List of the changes:

- add the `responseText` property to each `_request` implementation. The `jsonRequest` method now return an object with `{ body, responseText }` to properly resolve the cached value. It brings consistency in the `jsonRequest` response, we can now safely use both of the attributes.
- update the `jsonRequest` method to cache the result of `doRequest` instead of caching the raw response
- **EDIT**: enable the caching of request behind an option `_useRequestCache`. By default this option is `false` in that case the behaviour is the same as today. The user can choose to enable this option with `_useRequestCache: true`.

Questions:

- I didn't found a way to test the different builds. The PR adds the `responseText` to each of the implementation but I don't know how to test that the `_request` method correctly return the response.
- Some implementation might rely on the `cache` attribute of the client. We don't document it but it's still accessible on the client instance. The type of the value cached change from string to a promise. ~~To avoid a BC we can introduce an option for handle different caching strategy with the default value on the previous implementation.~~
- We do clear the cache in case of error now. ~Last but not least since we cache the results of `doRequest` we also cache the error when the retry strategy fails. It means that on subsequent requests the error will be fetch from the cache instead of doing a new call. We can avoid this issue by clearing the cache in case of error, but it's **not implemented** in this PR.~

**Before**

![before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6513513/40587195-375a8d82-61cc-11e8-945d-7cc7c3c3bb94.gif)

**After**

![after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6513513/40587197-3b9d16d0-61cc-11e8-8551-e9d1c10d4ae2.gif)
comments:
>Some implementation might rely on the cache attribute of the client. We don't document it but it's still accessible on the client instance. The type of the value cached change from string to a promise. To avoid a BC we can introduce an option for handle different caching strategy with the default value on the previous implementation.

What if we threw a warning on accessing the `.cache` outside of the client? Should be possible right? 

Still of the opinion that I can't see a use case of anyone directly using `.cache` so it isn't really that important that the implementation changes

> I didn't found a way to test the different builds. The PR adds the responseText to each of the implementation but I don't know how to test that the _request method correctly return the response.

~What we could do is create a new unit test where you target the local server that is running and there we would do checks that when launching two searches at the same time, only one is received by the server.~ You did that already I think?

> Some implementation might rely on the cache attribute of the client. We don't document it but it's still accessible on the client instance. The type of the value cached change from string to a promise. To avoid a BC we can introduce an option for handle different caching strategy with the default value on the previous implementation.

Yes for the time being we could add an option to activate the new behaviour. It would allow us to be compatible, then next major we remove the old cache.

> We do clear the cache in case of error now.

Can you precise what you mean?

If an error occurs, we don‚Äôt want to cache that error, since it might fix itself, maybe latency was just bad for a minute or you‚Äôre offline and online later. Same as with current implication since we only cache the result
This is a nice addition, let's make it as a feature flag and release!

> I didn't found a way to test the different builds. The PR adds the responseText to each of the implementation but I don't know how to test that the _request method correctly return the response.

This is now tested via a functional/black box test I believe? If so we are good to go

> This is no more true right since you made it a feature flag?

Yep indeed when the feature is not enable the type of the cache remains the same. It changes only when we enable the option.

> This is now tested via a functional/black box test I believe? If so we are good to go

Almost all the tests use the `_jsonRequest` function.  This function use the `_request` implementation of each build so we should be good. What is was looking for is a unit test for each build.
Let's goooo!

Please add the option to the defintions of Typescript. 

TS2345: Argument of type '{ _useRequestCache: boolean; }' is not assignable to parameter of type 'ClientOptions | undefined'.

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/26904

note for the future @eglinetwork, anyone can do a PR to DefinitelyTyped. Currently TypeScript isn't an officially supported language for us, so we won't proactively update the typings unless for breaking changes, or things we are actively deprecating. Thanks for mentioning this though
commit_messages:
feat(cache): cache the requests instead of responses (#694)

If you pass `_useRequestCache: true` as an option to the client then the cache behaviour will change. If you launch two requests at the same time then only one request will be done while the two callbacks/promises will still be called/resolved.

Previously, the client would have made two requests instead of one.

This is implemented by filling the cache as soon as the request launches instead of waiting for the response to fill it.

body:
## Why

As reported by @vvo, `AlgoliaSearchCore.prototype.searchForFacetValues` does not work in IE11 because we rely on the native [`Promise.all()`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Promise/all) since #677.

## Solution

* Polyfill the `all()` method in each `client._promise` build
* Use `client._promise.all()` instead of `Promise.all()`

We can increase the bundle size threshold from 46kB to 46.5kB if you're OK with that.

Thanks!

Just to be clear, this is right now needed to make it easier for us internally to create fake clients from transformers, is that right?

---

On a side note:

Good way to also raise the fact that we have a dual API in all API clients where everything under index.* could maybe just be sitting in client.* with indexName being available for some of those methods as a parameter.

cc @julienbourdeau maybe worth investigating (client.*/index.* redundancy) while reviewing the APIs of Algolia APIs clients (meta!)

> Just to be clear, this is right now needed to make it easier for us internally to create fake clients from transformers, is that right?

It is actually more than that. Let's say you want to implement Elasticsearch on a custom backend with InstantSearch like [this example](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-transformers/blob/707e6982470d6ce3be3e639b718e93e31ad82797/packages/elasticsearch-transformer/examples/concerts-server/index.js#L58). You'd need to use `search()` and `initIndex.searchForFacetValues()` (instead of `searchForFacetValues()`). With this new API method, you could skip the "pointless" `initIndex()` call (from the user point of view).

To sum up, it would simplify the surface of the API that the user needs to know to use a custom backend implementation via a transformer.

Does that make sense?
If you're not using Algolia, why would you use the Algolia client backend?

@Haroenv Are you referring to the `concerts-server` example? This file has different endpoints to showcase all the possibilities. I'm not using `algoliasearch` for the Elasticsearch endpoints, but for the custom Algolia endpoint.

Obviously I'm in favor of that PR, since I discussed it with @francoischalifour beforehand.

After discussing it with @Haroenv who had some reserve about it, there is a slight problem. This feature pushes for simplicity and symmetry. However this does not have complete symmetry with search. It is not able to do a multi index SFFV.

And that sounds like an actual good idea since we have a use case for this: a smart search box that would be able to complete facet values over multiple facetted attributes. Implementing the multi index search for facet values would be an enabler of such new UI pattern.

Agreed on implementing .searchForFacetValues([{indexName, ...}]).

About the example on https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-transformers/blob/707e6982470d6ce3be3e639b718e93e31ad82797/packages/elasticsearch-transformer/examples/concerts-server/index.js#L58, I understand now why it's easier to have searchForFacetValues at the root for such usecase where you really want to have the transformer acting on the backend and not on the frontend.
I'm going to update this PR to pass an array of queries to `searchForFacetValues()`. It turns out it's not an easy task because of the testing environment current limitations.
@francoischalifour seems like the test fails because `plan(xxx)` is different than the number of assertions in one of them

@Haroenv It is too painful to unit test this new feature because of the current way we deal with unit tests (our custom framework). I've tested the feature with a integration test and it works fine (@bobylito approved verbally).

Let me know what you think!

Android testing environnement is buggy right now using SauceLabs, I removed it. The fact that we are already testing Chrome is already a good test coverage because Android uses Chrome too. And we have no specific code for Android devices today.

Zuul, our test runner is abandoned project and support for mobile browsers is limited (appium support).

test me

test me

test it

comments: Just confirmed that this fixes the examples

Thanks for fixing this! However, I want to express my frustration with how this code was released. The Travis CI build is still broken and you release new versions of the library without having a green build. This is really prohibitive to a good testing culture. Looking at the code change, this would have been easily caught by a unit test.

The effective result for us was a lot of the JavaScript on our website didn't work even after the fix was released, because of the way cdn.jsdelivr caches the content on the major version and we are bundling the code using the SDK with more JS with Browserify.

So indeed, we were affected, because we depend on just `/3/` from the CDN, but the cache invalidation there is not great when an immediate fix needs to be released.

@hkdobrev Thanks for jumping in here,

> I want to express my frustration with how this code was released. The Travis CI build is still broken and you release new versions of the library without having a green build. This is really prohibitive to a good testing culture. Looking at the code change, this would have been easily caught by a unit test.

You are totally right and I apologise for the mess this created on your side. We have been pushing back updating our test suite setup for too long which have made us being less good at ensuring the stability of our JavaScript client.

Here are the steps we decided to take before any new release will happen on this client:
- remove the current set of tests that are using zuul
- replace them with single unit tests on node
- create a single good functional test with a real browser that will build the library and use it the way a user would use it (because unit tests are not always sufficient)
- remove any reference in our documentation and integration that is using /3/ because auto-updating is never a good idea. This is never the case on the backend, the fact that jsDelivr provides this is nice for POCs, not for production websites. You don't want your website to be updated by a third party.

> The effective result for us was a lot of the JavaScript on our website didn't work even after the fix was released, because of the day cdn.jsdelivr caches the content on the major version and we are bundling the code using the SDK with more JS with Browserify.

We just purged jsDelivr 30 minutes ago the right way so that /3/ is now delivering the right fix.

> So indeed, we were affected, because we depend on just /3/ from the CDN, but the cache invalidation there is not great when an immediate fix needs to be released.

Yes indeed the cache invalidation is tricky to handle well because of CDN cache and browser cache. Right now the version on jsDelivr is the right one though.

We advise you to move over to using a specific version. Since if your website is working on day one, and you don't need any new features, you can stay on a specific version. As we do as devs on backend dependencies, they are not auto update luckily.

Again sorry about this bad code change and release and thanks for the rapid feedback on it. We will ensure next releases are more robust.
The steps sound right and we already switched to a fixed version! Thanks for the update!
commit_messages: fix(protocol): avoid throwing when protocol found (#671)

body:
Originally the fact to use the page protocol or http by default was made
to speed up first requests to avoid initiating an https connection.

Nowadays this is no more of a big issue performance wise (citation
needed), but security wise, the use of http by default combined with
JSONP can be a big issue of MITM attacks.
comments: Releasing tomorrow
Is it released?
@asurak ready to release but just now had a doubt if this might not accidentally suppress the error when people run any of the methods we guard to only run on https
Never mind, was confused. That error is in the server, and that's why I didn't find it in the code base üëç
commit_messages:
feat(security): use https by default (#670)

Originally the fact to use the page protocol or http by default was made
to speed up first requests to avoid initiating an https connection.

Nowadays this is no more of a big issue performance wise (citation
needed), but security wise, the use of http by default combined with
JSONP can be a big issue of MITM attacks.

body:
Before this commit we were not listening for http network errors
that can happen once the connection is opened. Those can happen when you
have a network issue in the middle of a response.

I was able to reproduce this error by launching multiple requests and
unplugging my network altogether.

I would constantly get the infamous "zlib error" which was only an
effect of not being able to continue the response listening.
comments: This shouldn't be an issue on v4 since we handle `onError` already. Thanks for fixing it here!
commit_messages:
fix(nodejs): handle network errors (#669)

Before this commit we were not listening for http network errors
that can happen once the connection is opened. Those can happen when you
have a network issue in the middle of a response.

I was able to reproduce this error by launching multiple requests and
unplugging my network altogether.

I would constantly get the infamous "zlib error" which was only an
effect of not being able to continue the response listening.

comments:
I'm wondering if we should put the lint and this test before the functional one: 

```patch
diff --git a/scripts/test-ci b/scripts/test-ci
index aaed248..b35ab06 100755
--- a/scripts/test-ci
+++ b/scripts/test-ci
@@ -11,6 +11,12 @@ echo "CI test"
 echo "CI test: node"
 ./scripts/test-node

+echo "CI test: lint"
+./scripts/lint
+
+echo "Testing bundle size"
+bundlesize
+
 echo "CI test: browser"
 ./scripts/test-browser

@@ -20,9 +26,3 @@ else
   echo "CI test: parse-cloud"
   ./scripts/test-parse-cloud
 fi
-
-echo "CI test: lint"
-./scripts/lint
-
-echo "Testing bundle size"
-bundlesize
```

> I'm wondering if we should put the lint and this test before the functional one:

I would say having functional tests are more important than knowing the linting and size fails (i.e. I still want to be able to have the functional tests running even if I added a widget)

How does it works when the bundle size goes 1kb over ? Can we "accept it" somehow? Or do we have to raise the limit?
Accepting would be raising the limit in package.json @vvo, since it's a "staying" thing
commit_messages:
chore(sizing): add bundlesize (#621)

This will test on PR. Now I just added 1kb more than the current size so we don't accidently go above it by a lot and we explicitly know which file has which limit.

This is also used in instantsearch.js

<!--
  Thanks for submitting a pull request!
  Please provide enough information so that others can review your pull request.
-->

**Summary**

<!--
  Explain the **motivation** for making this change.
  What existing problem does the pull request solve?
  Are there any linked issues?
-->

copyIndex accepts an optional third argument with the scope

**Result**

<!--
  Demonstrate the code is solid.
  Example: The exact commands you ran and their output,
  screenshots / videos if the pull request changes UI.
-->

copyIndex can now accept a third parameter (scope) which is an array with values 'settings', 'synonyms', 'rules'. An empty array is treated as not given, since the api otherwise returns an error, and I have the feeling that this might be what people expect.

You can still have the callback as third argument if you want, or leave the third undefined and put it in the fourth position.

I added new tests with a valid array, empty array and undefined.

Wanted to test if callback is accepted on both position 3 and 4, but that seems to be quite hard, so for now I'll just let this be.
commit_messages:
feat(copyIndex): back-compatible add of scope (#618)

copyIndex can now accept a third parameter (scope) which is an array with values 'settings', 'synonyms', 'rules'. An empty array is treated as not given, since the api otherwise returns an error, and I have the feeling that this might be what people expect.

You can still have the callback as third argument if you want, or leave the third undefined and put it in the fourth position.

I added new tests with a valid array, empty array and undefined.

Wanted to test if callback is accepted on both position 3 and 4, but that seems to be quite hard, so for now I'll just let this be.

body:
We renamed this one in v4 because it's not really proper English

- [x] [wiki entry](https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/wiki/Deprecated#indexwaittask)
- [x] alias in v3
- [x] v4 implementation
comments: Where's waitForCompletion implemented?
It's not implemented yet in v3, forgot to push that

May need to update tests too.

Is waitForCompletion the new waitTask for all API clients?
I think it was originally @codeharmonics suggesting this change
Java has `waitForCompletion`, Scala `waitFor`, other ones have `waitTask`, `wait_task`

I feel like we should try to keep some consistency.
If we are to rename methods like these, we should validate them with the API maintainers and implement the change everywhere?
Java and Scala are the exceptions here if I'm not mistaken.
I agree with @rayrutjes, not sure we want to introduce a new wording here. This method should anyway never be used for something else that testing purposes.

@clement-leprovost started a discussion about renaming waitTask. Everybody agreed that it needed to be more explicit - wait for the task to do what???  Some suggested waitForTask, waitForTaskToComplete, or waitForCompletion.

@rayrutjes Doc team will be revisiting our API client methods, adding exact parameters and return results, as well as more code samples. We can start creating a list of name changes. But I'm curious how we manage interface changes? Can old clients still use the existing names? Are new clients encouraged or even required to use the new names?
If this is too contentious of a name change I can keep it like it is, but I only made this PR because we discussed it on Slack and it was on my TODO
Reverting this. We will reconsider this kind of naming on a global level at a later stage

All methods that will be removed are now deprecated, with a wiki page about them

- [x] write wiki pages

see #569

It should be good to go now, I wrote the wiki pages too for those added here, but I see that there are some older ones that don't have an anchor yet there. Will add those later.

wiki: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-javascript/wiki/Deprecated

I also fixed `deprecatedMessage` a bit so that it works with parameters in the function call

body:
**Summary**

There's no way to check an extra header or remove one, so that needed to be done

**Result**

```js
client.setExtraHeader('X-cool-header','hello there');
client.getExtraHeader('X-cool-header'); //hello there
client.deleteExtraHeader('X-cool-header');
client.getExtraHeader('X-cool-header'); //undefined
```

Do I need to add more documentation for this somewhere?

cc @alexandremeunier 

closes #571
comments: As noted in [rfc7230](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-3.2.2), [rfc2616](http://greenbytes.de/tech/webdav/rfc2616.html#message.headers) and [Stack Overflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39735299/is-an-http-client-allowed-to-send-multiple-headers-with-the-same-name) you can't really have multiple headers with the same name, if that's the case, you should send an array, instead of calling setExtraHeader multiple times

> Do I need to add more documentation for this somewhere?

Maybe, check doc repository and search for setExtraHeader
`setExtraHeader` is not documented, so there‚Äôs no need to add documentation for these methods either üòÑ
Merging, since the build fails at the same IE8 point as before
commit_messages:
feat(headers): add functions to remove and get extra headers (#572)

```js
client.setExtraHeader('X-cool-header','hello there');
client.getExtraHeader('X-cool-header'); //hello there
client.unsetExtraHeader('X-cool-header');
client.getExtraHeader('X-cool-header'); //undefined
```

Do I need to add more documentation for this somewhere?

cc @alexandremeunier @vvo

body:
**Summary**

Use console.warn rather than console.log This is the same thing as Facebook uses for React, and is more visible than a simple console.log. It is [supported](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Console/warn#Browser_compatibility) in IE8, so that should be fine

Slightly related to #569

**Result**

Deprecation warnings are now in yellow and marked as a warning so we can remove them with more ease later.
comments: üëå  I see no issue with the move. Thanks a lot.

This is the same thing as Facebook uses for React, and is more visible than a simple console.log

Because the changelog wasn't being rendered as markdown before now, we didn't notice that the indentation was being inconsistent (2, 4 and 6 spaces in the same file), and thus it wouldn't render properly. This PR fixes that, and all bullet points are now using 2 spaces for indentation, which gets rendered as proper markdown.

comments: I'm always confused when it comes to acronyms... whether we should camelCase them or not :/ I think I would have written `listAPIKeys()` instead of `listApiKeys()` but no strong opinion.

> I'm always confused when it comes to acronyms... whether we should camelCase them or not :/ I think I would have written listAPIKeys() instead of listApiKeys() but no strong opinion.

I would also prefer to always write api as API even in this case, so listAPIKeys(). Wonder if it's a real struggle or just another OCD.

Our chosen spec was to use listApiKeys form from what I read and see what's implemented already in other clients: https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-client-php/commit/c9bdad396d871fbc11022c1fa82e43d6b0333bcb

Still using API in comments.

Same feeling @redox I think it all comes down to personal prefs and consistency in projects.
I use both notations depends on the project. Personally I prefer the Api approach, because when you need to convert to first char to lower, you end up with aPI otherwise.

Very common acronyms (i.e. not OUR acronyms, like applicationID, we ditched this in favour of applicationId or appId) should stay capitalized from my POV. React thinks the same: https://facebook.github.io/react/docs/dom-elements.html#dangerouslysetinnerhtml

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123822/23801314/0b90ec60-05b0-11e7-8296-4e6008fb34ce.png)

But at the same time, they have:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/123822/23801326/12d1079e-05b0-11e7-93e7-b2a788beee95.png)

So is the rule:
- when acronym is in leading position: lowercase?
- when acronym is in trailing position: uppercase?
htmlFor comes from the DOM API https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLLabelElement/htmlFor
this ships on monday so we can follow the deployment

body:
This pull request will make sure the `process` variable is set prior to using it.

This is currently not an issue regarding the existing browser builds because `envify` will take care if initializing the `process` variable.

That being said, if some user wants to bundle the client in UMD format for example, then he will need to specify the following in his build:

```js
// Rollup example
replace({
      'process.env.NODE_ENV': JSON.stringify('production'),
      'process.env.RESET_APP_DATA_TIMER': 120000,
    }),
```

Unless this is indeed the expected behaviour, this PR solves the issue.

I'm wondering about the `NODE_ENV` though. Maybe we do want the users to override it that way, it is kinda common. With this PR, we can not simply "replace" it because we first check the `process`.

Happy to have your feedback on this.
Same as https://github.com/algolia/algoliasearch-helper-js/pull/482
comments:
I have yet one warning that needs to be addressed for the server build:
```
'default' is not exported by 'node_modules/rollup-plugin-node-builtins/src/es6/http.js'
https://github.com/rollup/rollup/wiki/Troubleshooting#name-is-not-exported-by-module
commonjs-proxy:node_modules/rollup-plugin-node-builtins/src/es6/http.js (1:173)
1: import * as http from "node_modules/rollup-plugin-node-builtins/src/es6/http.js"; export default ( http && http['default'] ) || http;
```
The server build needs some testing to be sure.
Please note that the server ES6 build has not been tested yet. Please do not rush this ;)

Given that in the client we have different builds for browser and the client, it would currently mean creating 2 separate es2015 module. Problem being there should only be one.

Given we can't leverage tree shaking and that we can not have 1 single es2015 module that covers all the use cases, I'll close this.

For ES6 projects, users will have to choose wether to user the `browser` field or not depending on the target platform and transform es5 exports to es6 exports.

Even if it looks like @rayrutjes has been struggling all alone with this, we have been following this internally together. We do want to make the JS client modern by providing more ES6/modules goodness. The JS community around tree shaking/modules/es6/export/import is still very young but most tooling is getting ready for the big jump. We will do it more probably this year.

Hello,

I was wondering if there was an issue to follow the work on ESModules? I'm especially interested in importing modules without a bundler (like webpack and browserify).

@oncletom, there's currently no issue opened about this, but there's general modernisation work we will do which should include es modules at some point, it's just that the experiment we did here proved that we had some extra complexity we didn't expect (especially with node for example). 

However, you can use it without bundling by using the UMD bundle: 

```html
<script src="https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/algoliasearch@3.30.0/dist/algoliasearch.min.js"></script>
```

**Summary**

Currently there is no way to specify an algolia agent at search time. The parameter `x-algolia-agent` is just ignored.

**Result**

This PR let the user specify a new Algolia agent the parameter `x-algolia-agent` (like with the REST API) and it will be appended to the ones specified with `addAlgoliaAgent`.

Fixes #493
