Before this commit, Node.js implementation had only a complete timeout
of 30s. Without any connect timeout.

Now Node.js has a 2s connect timeout, 5s read timeout, 30s write
timeout as per specifications, cc @asurak

There's also an opportunity to add connect timeout handling to
frontend users. Should we? If so, what would be a good connect timeout
knowing that we already have lowered the "read" timeout for instance.
commit_messages:
feat(retry strategy): multiple enhancements

This brings:
- Node.js proper timeouts
Before this commit, Node.js implementation had only a complete timeout
of 30s. Without any connect timeout.

Now Node.js has a 2s connect timeout, 5s read timeout, 30s write
timeout as per specifications, cc @asurak
- Browser build proper timeouts
1s connect
2s read
30s write
- Last known worked timeout is reused and shared as appIdData (localstorage or module wise), just as the hostIndex
- Current hostIndex shared is now write/read
- Refactored the shared appId data handling and resetting
- upgraded deps that could be upgraded
- added tests around new retry strategy (integration, unit)
- removed phantomjs testing, not valuable, buggy

body:
This commit adds another layer of HA by remembering the last known
work host for one minute.

The cache keys are either:
- domain + appId + browser => Browser localStorage
- process/pageLoad + appId => Node.js, Browser fallback

This is still a bit raw I think, have some review.

body: PR

Before this commit, methods with no fallback support (basically every
method but search) would fail at retry if the DNS error occured before the API
client timeout.

The behavior is now:
- when a method with a fallback errors because of DNS failure we will
  switch to JSONP right away
- when a method with no fallback errors because of DNS failure we will
  still retry

We could use the same mechanism for both (= always try all hosts
before JSONP) but I am not confident doing this change within a patch
or minor version. We have too litle data on how blocked XHRS are
triggered (async, sync?).

fixes #250

body: Update README

I have removed lodash from all browser builds.

File sizes:
- algoliasearch.min.js gzipped will weight 14.06 kB
- algoliasearch.angular.min.js gzipped will weight 14.47 kB
- algoliasearch.jquery.min.js gzipped will weight 14.31 kB
- algoliasearchLite.min.js gzipped will weight 9.57 kB (New build)

Previous version:
- algoliasearch.min.js gzipped will weight 19.08 kB
- algoliasearch.angular.min.js gzipped will weight 19.52 kB
- algoliasearch.jquery.min.js gzipped will weight 19.31 kB

The debug module we use along with the Promise polyfill are 3-4kb so we will be able to shave more in V4:
1. remove promise polyfill and provide the right polyfill to use
2. make debug module lighter

body:
Now providing a lite browser build:
- search only
- vanilla JS only (no angular, jquery lite builds for now)
- same export name (`algoliasearch`)
- now 5.93kb gzipped (versus 20kb)
- IE11/10/9 not natively supported, use http://cdn.polyfill.io/v2/docs/
  or just provide the Promise polyfill in the global object (window)
- same init usage
- has
  client.search/index.search/clearCache/setRequestTimeout/setExtraHeader/..
- no write/indexing/waitTask/settings methods => search only
- available on jsDelivr using algoliasearchLite[.min].js
- also requireable using
  var algoliasearch = require('algoliasearch/dist/algoliasearchLite.js');

fixes #215

body: Add CDNJS

When using the readme, I've hit a couple of issues that create extra confusion or unnecessary overhead. So I've:
- removed extra redirections
- added HTTPS by default on all www.algolia.com
  - since www.algolia.com has HSTS, the browser will do it automatically but if it a first request, there is unnecessary delay in reaching the documentation caused by the redirection to HTTPS
- fixed non-existent anchors to the documentation
  - most of the used anchors don't exist in the documentation anymore and the URLs had old format

body:
Our modules can be used in two ways:
- direct npm dependent
- `<script>` on jsDelivr

We were previously using "pinned" dependencies (1.2.3), I have switched them to ^1.2.3, mostly to avoid code duplication.

To tackle code duplication in modules using us as a direct
dependency, I switched all direct dependent to ^x.x.x version.

This means "We are compatible with any minor/patch version you may
already have for this dependency". This allow the host project(s) to
avoid code duplication.

As for the builded files, I added an npm-shrinkwrap.json file to lock
down our dependencies.

This has a very nice advantage that now we do control the result of
the build being pushed on jsdelivr. While previously it was up to the
developer node_modules state.

Since we have an npm run release task and since it's doing `npm
install`, we will always end up with a build where the dependencies
are locked.

The dev dependencies stays the same because there's no clear win to
auto upgrade them BUT break the build :)

If that's allright, I will also do this for the helper.

We were not setting the right headers previously

Now setting
- accept: application/json and
- content-type: 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' (POST)
- content-type: 'application/json' (PUT)

fixes #111

# lodash-compat?

So that we will share more code with the helper and the upcoming
places client.

The build size goes up from 14kb to 17kb.
# uglifyjs

Because, JAVA.

- `browse(query, queryParameters)` now has the same signature than
  search(). You can use any `query` and `queryParameters`.
- `browseFrom(cursor)` can be used as an efficient way to
  continue (next page) a previous `browse()` call. All browse responses now have a `cursor` property.
- `browseAll(query, queryParameters)` can be used to get all
  the content of your index
  It returns an [EventEmitter](https://nodejs.org/api/events.html).
  
  Available events:
  - `result`
  - `end`
  - `error` (you should listen to it or it will throw)
  
  There's also `stop()` method on the event emitter so that you can
  stop browsing at any point.

fixes #101

body:
- Externalize plugins and request implementations
- NEW FEATURE, All calls are now returning promises.
  - If there's a callback given to an API call, you won't get a promise.
  - Here are the different promises implementations we use:
    - Native promises by default (https://github.com/jakearchibald/es6-promise/)
    - AngularJS promises for AngularJS plugin
    - jQuery promises for jQuery plugin

fixes #44 #45

body:
- BREAKING CHANGE, no more window.ALGOLIA_VERSION
  - you can find the version in algoliasearch.version
- UMD compatibiliy #41
  - algoliasearch can now be used with any module loader
  - build is now done with browserify
  - no more grunt
- added simple test on `algoliasearch.helper()`
- removed vendor/
  - vendor/json2.js now as an npm module
  - vendor/jquery.typeahead.js now on cdnjs (examples)

fixes #41
commit_messages: Merge ca2d2a845952e77fab45e46d3c93ab50042710b8 into bbb7ba26556f6977b5e42aedeaa1ebb0fda4d250

body:
BREAKING CHANGE, changed initialization from `new AlgoliaSearch()` =>
`algoliasearch()` #40
- The only exported global property is now `algoliasearch`
- `opts`:
  - `dsnHost` removed, use `hosts:[dsnHost, other hosts]`
  - `dsn` removed, use `hosts:[non-dsn-host, non-dsn-host]`
  - `requestTimeoutInMs` renamed to `timeout`
  - `method` renamed to `protocol`. Protocol should be specified as
    `http:` or `https:`
  - `hosts` behavior changed, when using custom hosts:
    - no shuffling
    - no dsn host is prepended to the list
- removed `AlgoliaExplainResults`, no obvious use ATM
- calling algoliasearch() without an applicationID or apiKey will
  throw
- Helper: `new AlgoliaSearchHelper()` => `algoliasearch.helper()`,
  same function signature

resulting in fixing IE8 ajax requests

cc @redox @bobylito

resulting in fixing IE8 ajax requests

cc @bobylito @redox

- XHR/XDR uses .timeout. It's always available and sends timeout events
- XDR now reads the status property if any and act accordingly
- try/catch around JSON.parse to suppress uncaught errors
- JSONP fixes:
  - separate onload/onreadystatechange
  - global counter
  - tests on all browsers, OK from IE8 to IE11

Request strategy now well tested.

Maybe some tests missing, but that's enough to be able
to refactor/go V3.

  events

- JSONP fixes:

- global counter

Request strategy now well tested.

Maybe some tests missing, but that's enough to be able
to refactor/go V3.

body:
This seems to make more sense when changing things like number of hits
returned on subsequent "search" calls after the first init.

Let me know if this breaks an intended logic, but it seems to me that if
I explicitly supply settings to a search then they should be used over
the defaults or init variables.

Including public methods for controlling the state of the helper before
starting a search. This has been very useful when creating "facet UI's"
which have hierarchical data structures, adding fully featured paging
controls and dealing with infinity scroll.
